text: Back before Spellbooks were common, one casting method prevailed:
$(br)
$(l)Verbal Casting$()!
This is maybe the most straightforward way to cast spells:
Simply type the full spell in chat.
Verbal Casting comes with some advantages and drawbacks.
One of the most obvious advantages is the flexibility that comes with not
being tied to a specific tome and spell.
When testing spells, or using one that may need to be tweaked slightly during use,
you may want to consider using verbal casting to avoid writing libraries worth of books.
One less obvious advantage is that spells cast verbally do not $(o)technically$() have
any kind of cost limit.
This can be misleading, however.
As with the advantages, there is an obvious drawback when it comes to casting verbally:
$(br)
You have to type out (or paste) the spell each time you use it.
That's not all, however.
Casting verbally still introduces a cooldown after the spell is cast, and one that is notably
higher than the same spell cast from a Spellbook.
Additionally, while spell cost is not limited, casting costly spells can be detrimental to your
health, causing fatigue, hunger, and even directly injuring you.
Be careful!
